subject: Re: [junit] Writing tests first
msgSnippet: ... That is exactly correct. Typically, you write ONE test, make it compile, then make it pass. Then you write the next test, and so on. You go back and forth
messageBody:
On Fri, 10 Sep 2004 14:30:06 -0000, sharpe_simon <s.sharpe@...> wrote:
> I hope to use JUNIT to teach programming to my Y1 students this year.
> I'd planned to write the test class, then ask the students to write
> the code e.g for a Book class, a test in the TestBook class might
> look like this.
>
> public void testPrice()
> {
> Book b1 = new Book();
> b1.setPrice(7.99);
> assertEquals(7.99, b1.getPrice(), 0.0799);
> }
>
> Sudents should write the set and get methods and set values
> correctly so this test is passed.
>
> Problem : - I want them to work through the exercises and tests one
> at a time, but the test class will obviously not compile until all
> of the correct methods are in place in the Book class.
> Is my approach to this incorrect. Is there better way?

That is exactly correct. Typically, you write ONE test, make it
compile, then make it pass. Then you write the next test, and so on.
You go back and forth between having all tests passing, and having
(usually) just the one you are working on fail.

If you need to have all tests written in advance, you may have to do
something a bit more complex. For example, you could provide versions
of your test suite, with each version having one more test than the
one before it. Students would then have to download the tests, one by
one. That would be horrible to maintain.

Or you could provide a printed sheet of the tests (or an electronic
copy) and have them copy one test at a time into their test classes.
That is much easier and not much of an imposition for the students.

Ideally, of course, you teach them to write the tests for themselves.
That is really the best way, but you might use one of the other
approaches first if they are not ready.
